## Install Git  

Before we can explore branches, commits, or portfolios, we need **Git**â€”the free tool that remembers every version of your files.  
Think of Git as **â€œTrack Changes on steroids.â€** Once itâ€™s on your computer, everything else in this module becomes a click-along exercise rather than abstract theory.

> **Good news:** installation is usually a one-time, 5-minute job.  
> If you get stuck, post a screenshot in the Canvas **#git-help** thread and tag a TA; weâ€™ll unblock you quickly.

### What *is* Git, anyway?  *(skip if youâ€™re eager to install)*

* A **version-control system**: it stores snapshots of your project so you can rewind or compare any point in time.  
* A **collaboration diary**: when you work with partners, Git shows who changed what (and when), preventing accidental overwrites.  
* A **requirement for this course**: your assignments will be graded by cloning (downloading) your repo, so Git has to live on your laptop.

#### Install Git

*macOS (option 1 â€“ easiest)*  
```bash
xcode-select --install             # pops up â€œCommand Line Toolsâ€
```

*macOS (option 2 â€“ Homebrew)*  
```bash
/bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"
brew install git
```

*Ubuntu / Debian*  
```bash
sudo apt update
sudo apt install git
```

*Fedora / RHEL*  
```bash
sudo dnf install git         # Fedora
sudo yum install git         # RHEL 8-
```

> **What does `sudo` mean?**  
> â€œSuper-User DOâ€â€”temporarily grants admin rights (like Windows â€œRun as administratorâ€).  
> Youâ€™ll type your password; it wonâ€™t show on screenâ€”thatâ€™s normal.  
> Use `sudo` **only** when a trusted guide (like this lesson) tells you to.

#### File-Path Cheat Sheet â€” Backslash (`\`) vs Forward (`/`)

| Where you are | Path looks like | Example |
|---------------|----------------|---------|
| **File Explorer / PowerShell** | **Backslashes** \\ | `C:\Users\You\Desktop` |
| **Git Bash / Linux / macOS** | **Forward slashes** / | `C:/Users/You/Desktop` |

*Git Bash understands both*, but its own output always shows **forward slashes**.  
So when this guide says:

```bash
cd C:/Users/You/Documents
```

you **could** type:

```bash
cd C:\Users\You\Documents
```

and it would still work.

> **Pro tip:** If the path has spaces, wrap it in quotes:  
> `cd "C:/Users/You/My Projects/ds101"`.

### Configure Git on Your Computer  

> Youâ€™re telling Git, â€œWhenever I save a snapshot, tag it with *this* name & email,  
> use *this* editor, call the branch *main*, and remember my PAT so you donâ€™t nag me.â€  
> You run these **once per machine** (or whenever you want to change a setting).

> **What are these tables?**  
> Each table below is a â€œcheat-sheet.â€  
> * **Command** â€“ the exact text you type (copy-paste is fine).  
> * **Plain-English meaning** â€“ what you should hear in your head when you run it.  
> * **Example** â€“ a realistic usage with placeholders filled in.  
> * **Why you need it** â€“ the practical reason first-year DS students will care.  
> Skim the **meaning** column first; if it sounds useful, glance right for the
> example and try it in your own terminal. Replace anything in *italics* or
> `<angle-brackets>` with your info.

| Command | Plain-English meaning | Example | Why you need it |
|---------|----------------------|---------|-----------------|
| `git --version` | â€œDo I have Git, and which one?â€ | `git --version` â†’ `git version 2.44.0` | Quick sanity check after install. |
| `git config --global user.name "Jane Doe"` | â€œStamp my work with this name.â€ | `git config --global user.name "Brian C. Alvarez"` | Commits show up under your real name on GitHub. |
| `git config --global user.email "you@example.com"` | â€œâ€¦and this email.â€ | `git config --global user.email "brian@example.com"` | Matches commits to your GitHub account for contribution graphs. |
| `git config --global credential.helper store` | â€œRemember my PAT so I type it once.â€ | *(run once, then push)* | Avoids re-entering token each push. |
| `git config --global init.defaultBranch main` | â€œCall new branches *main* instead of *master*.â€ | `git init` then `git branch` â†’ `main` | Keeps local + GitHub branch names consistent. |
| `git config --global core.editor "nano -w"` | â€œOpen Nano when Git needs me to edit.â€ | set VS Code instead: <br>`git config --global core.editor "code --wait"` | Pick an editor youâ€™re comfortable with for merge messages. |
| `git config --global color.ui auto` | â€œColor-code Gitâ€™s output.â€ | *(run once)* | Highlights adds (green) & deletes (red) in `git diff`. |
| `git config --list --show-origin` | â€œShow every setting & where it lives.â€ | `git config --list --show-origin` | Troubleshoot if something seems off. |
| `git config --edit --global` | â€œOpen the config file in my editor.â€ | `git config --edit --global` | Manual tweaks without memorizing commands. |

> **TIP:** The `--global` flag writes to a single file (`~/.gitconfig` on mac/Linux,  
> `%USERPROFILE%\.gitconfig` on Windows). Remove `--global` if you ever need a per-project override.

#### GitHub-specific Remote Commands *(youâ€™ll use these in Parts 2 & 4)*

> **Read this table like a recipe card**:  
> Youâ€™ll run these whenever you want to *connect* your local folder to the cloud,
> *sync* changes, or *grab* someone elseâ€™s work. Replace `URL` with the HTTPS
> link you copy from GitHub (it always ends in `.git`).

| Command | Plain-English meaning | Example | Why you need it |
|---------|----------------------|---------|-----------------|
| `git remote add origin URL` | â€œBookmark my repo on GitHub.â€ | `git remote add origin https://github.com/you/ds101.git` | Links **local** folder â†” **remote** repo. |
| `git remote -v` | â€œShow which remotes I have.â€ | `git remote -v` | Sanity check before pushing. |
| `git push -u origin main` | â€œUpload commits and set *origin/main* as default.â€ | *(after first commit)* | The `-u` flag means future `git push` can omit branch name. |
| `git pull origin main` | â€œGrab teammatesâ€™ latest work.â€ | `git pull origin main` | Always pull before you start editing. |
| `git clone URL` | â€œCopy the whole project (and its history).â€ | `git clone https://github.com/octocat/Hello-World.git` | First step when joining an existing repo. |

Keep this table handy; these six commands make up **90 %** of your day-to-day Git-for-GitHub life.

**ğŸ›ï¸ Option #1: Using GitHub Desktop**

### Generate & Store a Personal Access Token (PAT)

> GitHub no longer accepts account passwords for pushing code;  
> a **PAT** acts like a long, single-purpose password just for Git.

**ğŸ›ï¸ GUI Path (Recommended)**  

1. On GitHub.com: click your **profile picture** â–¸ **Settings**.  
2. Sidebar **Developer settings** â–¸ **Personal access tokens** â–¸ **Tokens (classic)**.  
3. Press **Generate new token (classic)**.  
4. Fill the form:  
   * **Note:** `ds101-pat`  
   * **Expiration:** 90 days is fine (you can always regenerate).  
   * **Scopes:** tick **repo** (gives push/pull rights).  
5. Click **Generate token** â†’ copy the long string that appears (starts with `ghp_`).  
6. **Store it once** when your tool asks:  
   * **GitHub Desktop:** it prompts automatically on first pushâ€”paste token as *password*.  
   * **RStudio:** run `gitcreds_set()` (see below) and paste when prompted.  
   * **Windows Credential Manager / macOS Keychain:** Git stores it after your first successful push, so youâ€™re not asked again.

**âŒ¨ï¸ Terminal Storage (universal fallback)**  

```bash
git config --global credential.helper store          # remember credentials
# The next time Git asks for "password", paste the PAT.
```

**R code helper (for RStudio fans)**  

```r
install.packages("usethis")
library(usethis)
gitcreds_set()   # Paste PAT when prompted; it's written to an encrypted store
```

> ğŸ”’ **Never** put your PAT inside a repository, email, or chat post. Treat it like a credit-card number.

## The Core Workflow â€” *Change â†’ Stage â†’ Commit â†’ Push* 

> You make a change, tell Git youâ€™re ready, write a short diary note, then send it to the cloud.  
> Same idea, two ways: **GUI first**, **terminal second**.

### GUI (GitHub Desktop)

1. **Open** the *Hello-World* repo in **GitHub Desktop**.  
2. In your file explorer (Finder / Explorer) open `README.md`, add this line at the bottom:

   ```
   Hello DS 101! ğŸ‰
   ```

3. **Save** the file; GitHub Desktop now shows the change in the *Changes* tab.  
4. Type a **summary**: `Add friendly greeting` â†’ click **Commit to main**.  
5. Click **Push origin** (upper-right).  
6. Wait for the green check âœ… that says **"Published"**.

### 6.2 Terminal

```bash
echo "Hello DS 101! ğŸ‰" >> README.md   # add a line
git status                            # Git sees it as 'modified'
git add README.md                     # stage the change
git commit -m "Add friendly greeting" # snapshot saved locally
git push origin main                  # upload to GitHub
```

If Git prompts, **username = your GitHub handle**, **password = PAT**.

## Common Pitfalls & Quick Fixes 

| ğŸ˜– Symptom | Likely Reason | ğŸš‘ Fix |
|------------|--------------|-------|
| Re-enter PAT every push | Helper not set | `git config --global credential.helper store` and push once more |
| `fatal: not a git repository` | Youâ€™re outside the project folder | `cd` into the folder that contains a hidden `.git` |
| Merge conflict markers `<<<<<<<` | Two people edited the same line | Decide which text to keep â†’ save â†’ `add` â†’ `commit` |
| `brew: command not found` (mac) | Homebrew missing | Install via <https://brew.sh> |
| `git: command not found` (Linux) | Git not installed | `sudo apt-get install git` (Debian) / `sudo dnf install git` (Fedora) |
